Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: They are listed as the sole speaker for this week's congregational sermon, and the community has publicized their topic.
Story:
This morning, I received a message from Ahmed, someone I know from the neighborhood. He’s moving to a new apartment and asked if I could help him carry some boxes. He sounded desperate—his brother canceled last minute, and he doesn’t have anyone else to turn to. As an acquaintance, I feel a responsibility to help. I know how hard it is to move alone, and I don’t want to let him down.

But today is Friday, and I am the imam scheduled to deliver the Khutbah. The community has already announced my topic, and I know many people are looking forward to it. There’s no one else to fill in; if I don’t show up, the congregation will be left without a sermon. The weight of both expectations presses on me. I want to be there for Ahmed, but I also can’t abandon my duty to the community. My mind races, torn between the immediate need of a friend and the collective trust of my congregation. I sit in silence, feeling the tension build inside me, unsure which path to take.
